title: Private list members disclosure via GraphQL

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
Due to improper queries of GraphQL, the attacker can steal members of the private list.

**Description:**
Twitter implements a unique GraphQL endpoint, which can use only the queries that Twitter specified. However, there is a flaw in the backend (https://api.████████.com/graphql/iUmNRKLdkKVH4WyBNw9x2A/ListMembers).
This vulnerability requires snowflake brute-force, but it's not impossible. Snowflake is built from the timestamp, sequence id, and worker id. Sequence id is basically 0 because it'll reset automatically at the start of every millisecond. Worker id can have 2 ^ 10 = 1024 different values in principle.
So you need to send 1024 * 1000 = 1024000 requests to perform brute-force snowflake which created in a sec.
1024000 * 60 = 61440000 requests will be enough to brute-force a list created in a minute.
It takes a few hours to perform, but it's not impossible.

## Steps To Reproduce:

To reproduce this:
1. Create a private list in account A and add some people.
1. Login to account B, and trigger `ListMembers` request.
1. Intercept the request and replace ID to the list's one which you created in step 1.
1. Now, you know the members of account A's private list from account B.

In real attack: 
  1. Send requests to `https://api.█████████.com/graphql/iUmNRKLdkKVH4WyBNw9x2A/ListMembers?variables=%7B%22listId%22%3A%22[Valid Snowflake Here]%22%2C%22count%22%3A20%2C%22includePromotedContent%22%3Atrue%2C%22withHighlightedLabel%22%3Atrue%2C%22withTweetQuoteCount%22%3Atrue%2C%22withTweetResult%22%3Atrue%7D` until you got valid response.
  1. If you found a valid snowflake, open `https://████████.com/i/lists/[ID Here]`.
  1. If the list is private, you know members of the list now.

## Supporting Material/References:

██████

## Impact

Leakage of private list members.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
Due to improper queries of GraphQL, the attacker can steal members of the private list.

Description:
Twitter implements a unique GraphQL endpoint, which can use only the queries that Twitter specified. However, there is a flaw in the backend (https://api.xn--4zhaaaaaaa.com/graphql/iUmNRKLdkKVH4WyBNw9x2A/ListMembers).
This vulnerability requires snowflake brute-force, but it's not impossible. Snowflake is built from the timestamp, sequence id, and worker id. Sequence id is basically 0 because it'll reset automatically at the start of every millisecond. Worker id can have 2 ^ 10 = 1024 different values in principle.
So you need to send 1024 * 1000 = 1024000 requests to perform brute-force snowflake which created in a sec.
1024000 * 60 = 61440000 requests will be enough to brute-force a list created in a minute.
It takes a few hours to perform, but it's not impossible.

Steps To Reproduce:

To reproduce this:

  1. Create a private list in account A and add some people.
  2. Login to account B, and trigger ListMembers request.
  3. Intercept the request and replace ID to the list's one which you created in step 1.
  4. Now, you know the members of account A's private list from account B.

In real attack:

  1. Send requests to https://api.█████████.com/graphql/iUmNRKLdkKVH4WyBNw9x2A/ListMembers?variables=%7B%22listId%22%3A%22[Valid Snowflake Here]%22%2C%22count%22%3A20%2C%22includePromotedContent%22%3Atrue%2C%22withHighlightedLabel%22%3Atrue%2C%22withTweetQuoteCount%22%3Atrue%2C%22withTweetResult%22%3Atrue%7D until you got valid response.
  2. If you found a valid snowflake, open https://████████.com/i/lists/[ID Here].
  3. If the list is private, you know members of the list now.

Supporting Material/References:

██████

Impact

Leakage of private list members.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report @ryotak ,

We have been able to reproduce the behavior you reported. However, after an investigation, we have determined that the disclosed information does not pose enough security risk to qualify for our program. Please keep in mind that our HackerOne program does not generally accept theoretical or potential reports, and requires that researchers demonstrate how the behavior they have found can be used in an attack.

The scenario suggested in your report, describes that it will require a considerable amount of requests to successfully exploit the attack in order to know the ID of the private listing. 

> So you need to send 1024 * 1000 = 1024000 requests to perform brute-force snowflake which created in a sec.
1024000 * 60 = 61440000 requests will be enough to brute-force a list created in a minute.

Please note that in order to stop attackers to send a large number of requests in a short period of time, we have rate-limiting mechanisms implemented at different levels (e.g. by IP address, by attempts per username, etc.), that will likely stop the brute-force attack.

Can you confirm if you are able to get other more sensitive information rather than the `screen_name` of the members of the list? (e.g. Tweets from private Twitter accounts). Can you confirm if you were able to bypass our rate-limiting mechanisms when conducting this attack?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Hello @bugtriage-christian,
I think I have found a way to ignore rate limits. I'm currently trying to create a PoC and test it. Here is how I achieved this.
First of all, some of Twitter's APIs do not have rate limits set properly.
As I looked deep into the API, I found that some APIs took and used List.
And I found that `POST /lists/destroy` responded a few milliseconds slower than usual when specifying an existing ID. And the exact response time can be obtained by checking the `x-response-time` header. (If ID does not exist: ~ 120ms, if it exists: ~ 150ms)
Therefore, you can use it to get a valid ID and then use the GraphQL endpoint above to try to get a private list member using an ID that exists for sure.
And the `workerId` was actually only 32 patterns.
I am currently sending a large number of requests to Twitter to test this, but I would appreciate if you wouldn't block my IP if possible.

Regards,
RyotaK
activities.markdown_message:

Therefore, you can use it to get a valid ID and then use the GraphQL endpoint above to try to get a private list member using an ID that exists for sure.
And the workerId was actually only 32 patterns.
I am currently sending a large number of requests to Twitter to test this, but I would appreciate if you wouldn't block my IP if possible.

Regards,
RyotaK

activities.message:
I found someone's private list using the technique described above: https://██████.com/i/lists/██████
Normally you will not be able to see this list, but you can see the list members by using the ListMembers query. (I won't save any of the information in the response as it is not viewable normally. You can test it in your computer.)
```
GET /graphql/iUmNRKLdkKVH4WyBNw9x2A/ListMembers?variables=%7B%22listId%22%3A%22██████████%22%2C%22count%22%3A20%2C%22includePromotedContent%22%3Afalse%2C%22withHighlightedLabel%22%3Afalse%2C%22withTweetQuoteCount%22%3Afalse%2C%22withTweetResult%22%3Afalse%7D
```

activities.message:
████████
Here is a PoC that exploits the above behavior to get a valid list ID.
It was possible (at least for me) to run this script for about an hour and get the ids of two valid private lists.

This script will continue to send requests to `POST /lists/destroy` with 64 threads and print to stdout if a valid id is found.
The Sequence of the target ID must be 0 and the Datacenter ID must be 10. (I will explain later why this does not cause any problems.)
If I run this script on my AWS instance (which costs only $20 a month), it is possible to brute force the list created within 1000 milliseconds in about 5 minutes with 50% accuracy.
Note that running this on your home computer is not recommended, as this script can send a lot of requests and fill up the traffic.

Set valid Twitter API credentials in environment variables named `CONSUMER_KEY`,` CONSUMER_SECRET`, `ACCESS_TOKEN`, and` ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET`, and execute it, then brute force will start with the ID two hours before the current time as the starting point.
It can take several hours to find a valid ID. Please leave it after executing.

The following is the reason why the Sequence is fixed to 0 and the Datacenter ID is fixed to 10.
See the table below.
```
Worker ID: 6 Count: 63
Worker ID: 1 Count: 55
Worker ID: 14 ​​Count: 55
Worker ID: 7 Count: 54
Worker ID: 12 Count: 52
Worker ID: 15 Count: 49
Worker ID: 16 Count: 45
Worker ID: 3 Count: 44
Worker ID: 23 Count: 42
Worker ID: 13 Count: 38
Worker ID: 27 Count: 1
Worker ID: 24 Count: 1
Worker ID: 25 Count: 1
Datacenter ID: 10 Count: 497
Datacenter ID: 11 Count: 3
Sequence: 0 Count: 241
Sequence: 1 Count: 144
Sequence: 2 Count: 52
Sequence: 3 Count: 20
Sequence: 5 Count: 15
Sequence: 6 Count: 11
Sequence: 4 Count: 7
Sequence: 7 Count: 3
Sequence: 8 Count: 3
Sequence: 9 Count: 2
Sequence: 11 Count: 1
Sequence: 10 Count: 1
```
This table lists the Snowflake ID contents that were generated when I submitted a request to create a list of 500.
As you can see from this table, Worker IDs are very random. Therefore, this value must be brute force.
However, the Datacenter ID is almost fixed, and about 50% of the Sequence is 0.
One reason why many Snowflake IDs have a Sequence of 0 is that the Sequence ID is reset at the start of every millisecond.
As a result, it is possible to brute force the list created in one second with 1000 * 32 = 32000 requests with a probability of about 50%.
This is a very low value considering that there is no rate limit in `POST /lists/destroy`.

Regards,
RyotaK

activities.message:
I have found that in some cases it is possible to read the subscribers of a list that should not be viewable.
This issue is caused by the GraphQL query `ListSubscribers`.
This query does not return the subscribers if the target list is a private setting, but returns the subscribers if the target list is a public setting on a private account.
Therefore, it leads to reading the subscribers of the list that cannot be viewed.
Should this issue be submitted as a separate report?

Regards,
RyotaK
activities.markdown_message:

Therefore, it leads to reading the subscribers of the list that cannot be viewed.
Should this issue be submitted as a separate report?

Regards,
RyotaK

activities.message:
Thank you for your response @ryotak,

According to the Twitter Developer [documentation](https://developer.████.com/en/docs/accounts-and-users/create-manage-lists/api-reference/post-lists-destroy), the `/lists/destroy` endpoint should be rate-limited, however, looks like you bypassed such controls. Could you provide us with the following information about the attack you conducted? Any other information will help us to investigate the behavior you reported.

1.  Could you provide us with an example of the `/lists/destroy` HTTP request when conducting the brute-force attack?
2.	How many requests were you ultimately able to send? (e.g. 1000 requests successfully sent).
3.	How fast were you able to send your requests? (e.g. 1000 requests were sent in 2 minutes).

About your previous comments, we'd like to ask you about what the terms `Worker`, `Datacenter` and `Sequence`, and their `ID`&`Count` mean. Could you provide us with an explanation about what the aforementioned terms, and how are they related to the `list` ID brute-forced? In addition, Can you confirm if you are able to get other more sensitive information rather than the `screen_name` of the members of the list? (e.g. Tweets from private Twitter accounts).

Finally, we would like to reproduce also the `ListSubscribers`'s behavior. Could you provide us with the HTTP request?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

  1. Could you provide us with an example of the /lists/destroy HTTP request when conducting the brute-force attack?
  2. How many requests were you ultimately able to send? (e.g. 1000 requests successfully sent).
  3. How fast were you able to send your requests? (e.g. 1000 requests were sent in 2 minutes).

About your previous comments, we'd like to ask you about what the terms Worker, Datacenter and Sequence, and their ID&Count mean. Could you provide us with an explanation about what the aforementioned terms, and how are they related to the list ID brute-forced? In addition, Can you confirm if you are able to get other more sensitive information rather than the screen_name of the members of the list? (e.g. Tweets from private Twitter accounts).

Finally, we would like to reproduce also the ListSubscribers's behavior. Could you provide us with the HTTP request?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Hello @bugtriage-christian,
Thank you for your reply!

Here are the answers to your question.

> Could you provide us with an example of the /lists/destroy HTTP request when conducting the brute-force attack?

Here is an example HTTP request (Note: This request was made by twileak.rb.): 

URL: `/1.1/lists/destroy.json`

Method: `POST`

Headers:
```
{
  "content-length": "27",
  "accept-encoding": "gzip;q=1.0,deflate;q=0.6,identity;q=0.3",
  "accept": "*/*",
  "user-agent": "OAuth gem v0.5.4",
  "content-type": "application/x-www-form-urlencoded",
  "authorization": "OAuth [Redacted]"
}
```

Body:
```
list_id=███████
```

(I already sent a script that reproduces this behavior. If you'd like to reproduce this, you can use it.)

> How many requests were you ultimately able to send? (e.g. 1000 requests successfully sent).

At least, I've sent over 96000 requests while brute-forcing the ID. It should be more since I also sent many requests while developing the script above.

> How fast were you able to send your requests? (e.g. 1000 requests were sent in 2 minutes).

About 32000 requests in 5 minutes. (In my AWS instance)

> About your previous comments, we'd like to ask you about what the terms Worker, Datacenter and Sequence, and their ID&Count mean. Could you provide us with an explanation about what the aforementioned terms, and how are they related to the list ID brute-forced?

ID of list is based on the snowflake ID. (Document [here](https://developer.██████████.com/ja/docs/basics/█████-ids)). These IDs are built from timestamps, worker ID (Worker number used to create this ID), datacenter ID (Datacenter number used to create this ID), and sequence (sequential number to prevent ID collision). These `IDs` and `Counts` are the actual content of the IDs generated when I submitted 500 requests and how many times they were generated.

(You can see the twileak.rb script I created to understand how the ID was created.)

> In addition, Can you confirm if you are able to get other more sensitive information rather than the screen_name of the members of the list? (e.g. Tweets from private Twitter accounts).

At least I don't think these pieces of information are leaking from this endpoint other than I reported in #885511. However, this issue can be an issue in the following cases:
1. A company employee has a private list of Twitter accounts for all employees of the company.
2. If the student has a private list of Twitter accounts for classmates
3. Someone has a private list of their hidden secret accounts

... etc

> Finally, we would like to reproduce also the ListSubscribers's behavior. Could you provide us with the HTTP request?

Here is an example HTTP request: 

```
GET /graphql/0se5fTpTWRNzrupcMxWTKg/ListSubscribers?variables=%7B%22listId%22%3A%22██████████%22%2C%22count%22%3A20%2C%22includePromotedContent%22%3Afalse%2C%22withHighlightedLabel%22%3Afalse%2C%22withTweetQuoteCount%22%3Afalse%2C%22withTweetResult%22%3Afalse%7D HTTP/1.1
Host: api.██████████.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:76.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/76.0
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: ja,en-US;q=0.7,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
content-type: application/json
authorization: Bearer [Redacted]
x-█████-auth-type: OAuth2Session
x-████████-client-language: ja
x-██████████-active-user: yes
x-csrf-token: [Redacted]
Origin: https://██████.com
DNT: 1
Connection: close
Referer: https://████████.com/
Cookie: [Redacted]
```

I'd like to open multiple reports. Because these vulnerabilities are completely different:
1. Private List Member disclosure (Current report)
2. Broken rate-limit for some APIs
3. Public List of Private account subscriber disclosure

Will you allow these reports?

Regards,
RyotaK

Host: api.██████████.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:76.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/76.0
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: ja,en-US;q=0.7,en;q=0.3

content-type: application/json
authorization: Bearer [Redacted]
x-█████-auth-type: OAuth2Session
x-████████-client-language: ja
x-██████████-active-user: yes
x-csrf-token: [Redacted]
Origin: https://██████.com
DNT: 1
Connection: close
Referer: https://████████.com/
Cookie: [Redacted]

I'd like to open multiple reports. Because these vulnerabilities are completely different:

  2. Broken rate-limit for some APIs
  3. Public List of Private account subscriber disclosure

Will you allow these reports?

Regards,
RyotaK

activities.message:
Thank you for your response @ryotak,

As we believe that the attack vector to exploit "*Private List Member disclosure*" and "*Public List of Private account subscriber disclosure*" is the "*Broken rate-limit for some APIs*", we will handle all of them within the same report. While it is true that the Graphl endpoints are different, without the rate-limit bypass, these issues do not pose enough security risk to the Twitter infrastructure or our users, as the attacks couldn't be conducted without the attacker having a valid listing ID.

We believe we have all the information to investigate this. We'll let you know if we need further information.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Hello @bugtriage-christian,
Thank you for the update!
From your reply, I'm assuming Twitter rated this report as:
The underlying vulnerability is API rate-limit avoidance, and GraphQL's vulnerabilities is increasing its impact.

Is this assumption correct? If so, should I send a list of endpoints that do not have rate limits set properly?

Also, I found a bug in twileak.rb, and have fixed it. (Attached below)

Regards,
RyotaK

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

activities.message:
Hello @unwobodo,
Thank you for the update!

I would like to explain this vulnerability in a private Lightning Talk at school (Held on June 25). However, it is not good to explain vulnerabilities that have not been fixed, so I would like to ask you about the plan for fixing.

Also, if necessary, I will send you a list of endpoints with rate limits not set properly. Should I send it?

Finally, is the severity of this vulnerability really Low? I'm confirming just in case.

Regards,
RyotaK

activities.message:
Hello @unwobodo,
Thank you for your reply!

I'm sorry, I accidentally sent a file containing JavaScript that was under development.
This JavaScript contained code to scan ██████████ (in short, ████████). I intended to send this after getting permission, but this time I mistakenly sent it as a slide for the presentation. I apologize for this.
Fortunately, this scan did not finished properly.
And I have some questions regarding this:
1. If a document explaining how to deploy to ███ is leaked, does Twitter treat it as a security risk?
2. Once I have completed this code, can you click the link to scan ████?

I am currently out and cannot upload slides for presentation. When I get home, I'll send you slides for the presentation.

Once again, I apologize for the incorrectly sent link.

Regards,
RyotaK

Can you redact this information? (Please answer regarding the above two questions that related to the string you will redact): 
Strings: `█████`, `██████`, `████████`, `███`,`██████`,`█████`, `██████████`
Attachments: `█████████`

Also, this is not directly related report, but can you check #921060? I've replied to the Twitter team 2 weeks ago.
Finally, as lightning talk has been postponed to the end of September, I'd like to create another presentation slide, so I'll send the presentation slide when it finished. (I'll finish it before 31st August)

Regards,
RyotaK

summaries.content:
## Summary
By chaining the timing attack and broken rate limit with a vulnerable GraphQL query, it was possible to read members of the private list via GraphQL.

## Description

### Starting
On May 28th, I noticed that Twitter has some weird endpoints.
That endpoint looked like this: `https://api.twitter.com/graphql/[Random String]/[Endpoint name]`.
After doing a Google search, I found [this page](https://about.sourcegraph.com/graphql/graphql-at-twitter).
According to this page, this is Twitter's GraphQL implementation, called `stored operations` or `persisted queries`.
I haven't heard about them, so I've searched Google, and there seems to be no example (as far as I've seen) found a vulnerability in this feature.
So I decided to dig deeper into this.

### Reconnaissance
This endpoint has a Random String part that makes enumeration difficult. As a result, it is difficult to find an endpoint by brute force.
So I started reading the JavaScript code for Twitter Web Client.
After a while, I noticed that main.[Hex string].js stores Endpoint name and Random String as a pair.
{F935327}
Therefore, I used the Wayback Machine to enumerate the past main.[Hex string].js and took out all the Endpoint name and Random String from it.
At this point, a sufficient amount was collected, but from the above article, it seems that GraphQL is used not only in Twitter Web Client but also in Twitter Mobile Client and Tweetdeck, so I decided to extract it from there.
In the code of Twitter Android Client, the pair of Endpoint name and Random String was stored in `l63.java`, and in Tweetdeck, it was `bundle.[Hex string].js`.
{F935329}
{F935328}
As a result, I have gathered a list of over 700 endpoints, so I decided to move to the next stage.

### Testing
Testing over 700 endpoints can be a daunting task, but existing GraphQL clients don't support this type of endpoint, so I started testing with Firefox and the Burp Suite.
The test was run for several hours, so I will only pick and explain what is important.
First, it seems that there is no problem if GraphQL's endpoint is just `/graphql`.
You can execute GraphQL by sending a POST request with `queryId` (this is the Random String above) and `variables` in Body to this endpoint. So the Endpoint name was not needed.
{F935324}
Second, some Query IDs will give an error when trying to reference a field that does not exist.
This is probably due to an attempt to execute an old query on the current schema.
{F935325}
After testing for a while, I concluded that it is impossible to execute arbitrary GraphQL queries.
That's why I decided to run the queries one by one and drill down into the interesting ones.
After a while, I focused on the `ListMembers` query.
It looks like this is a query that returns a list of members for a List. And there was no check that the target List was private or not in that query.

### Reporting
I found that I could retrieve the members of a private List using the `ListMembers` query (`iUmNRKLdkKVH4WyBNw9x2A`), so I reported this to Twitter.
A few hours later, there was a reply from the Twitter Security Team, but it seems that the Twitter team thinks the Twitter ID is difficult to brute force.
I thought that brute force is possible, so I tried creating a script to try brute force. However, due to the existence of rate limits, it was not possible to brute force.

### Bypassing
Direct brute force cannot be done because the rate limit of GraphQL itself cannot be avoided. However, the List-ID is not unique to GraphQL and is used in various APIs. Therefore, I decided to try using these APIs to see if brute force is possible.
Fortunately, Twitter's API rate limits were mostly broken. Even though Twitter's developer docs said that there was a rate limit, there were many that didn't.
However, it seems that there is no vulnerability in the API of Twitter that leaks information on the private List, and it is not possible to confirm the existence of the private List.
At this point, I was considering self-closing the report. But it was not fun to give up here, so I decided to explore more possibilities.
After a few minutes, I noticed the presence of the `x-response-time` header. This seems to be returning the time used for processing on the server-side.
I immediately confirmed the difference in the `x-response-time` header when specifying the ID of the private List and when specifying the ID that does not exist.
There was a slight difference (10-20ms) in processing time between private List ID and non-existent ID. Using this, I can enumerate the IDs on any private List.
{F935330}

### Exploiting
After creating a PoC that enumerates a List using the above vulnerabilities, I was hungry and decided to eat ramen.
Before I went to eat ramen, I deployed PoC to AWS and ran it.
After returning home, I checked my AWS instance and rejoiced.
`Potential List Detected: [Real List ID] (With 137ms delay)`
It looks like I found valid private List ID...
And yes, I've confirmed that I can read members of any private List!

### Conclusion
I think this report is a good report showing that even a small vulnerability (confirmation of the existence of a private List) that is not normally recognized as a valid report can produce a greater effect by being linked with other vulnerabilities.
Also, by using the same technique like this one, you can enumerate all the Moments using the link-only sharing option that exists in Twitter's Moment function, but this does not seem to be a vulnerability (Twitter closed it as Informative.)
{F935326}
Unfortunately, when I was looking for a Twitter vulnerability after this report, my account was suspended. (I haven't received a reply from the support team yet...) 
(Edit: My account got unsuspended)
So I can't find any more Twitter vulnerabilities. Therefore, I'll share here some of the interesting information I found during my research. (If you find vulnerabilities based on this information, I would be grateful for a word of thanks.)

#### PoC files
{F935333}: It'll find unlisted moments (Intended behavior)
{F935334}: It'll find valid List ID

#### Twitter GraphQL Query IDs

{F935320}
{F935321}
{F935322}
{F935323}

#### About protected tweets option

Twitter's protected tweets option only protects Tweets. It won't protect Lists, Followers... etc.
If you're using a protected account and sharing some sensitive information in Lists, be careful with it. (Twitter said this is intended behavior.)

#### Broken rate limits

After sending this report, I deleted the list of endpoints that have the broken rate limit. And as my account got suspended, I can't test it anymore. So please find it by yourself.

If you have any questions, ask me on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ryotkak) ;)
summaries.content_html:
Summary

By chaining the timing attack and broken rate limit with a vulnerable GraphQL query, it was possible to read members of the private list via GraphQL.

Description

Starting

On May 28th, I noticed that Twitter has some weird endpoints.
That endpoint looked like this: https://api.twitter.com/graphql/[Random String]/[Endpoint name].
After doing a Google search, I found this page.
According to this page, this is Twitter's GraphQL implementation, called stored operations or persisted queries.
I haven't heard about them, so I've searched Google, and there seems to be no example (as far as I've seen) found a vulnerability in this feature.
So I decided to dig deeper into this.

Reconnaissance

This endpoint has a Random String part that makes enumeration difficult. As a result, it is difficult to find an endpoint by brute force.
So I started reading the JavaScript code for Twitter Web Client.
After a while, I noticed that main.[Hex string].js stores Endpoint name and Random String as a pair.

Therefore, I used the Wayback Machine to enumerate the past main.[Hex string].js and took out all the Endpoint name and Random String from it.
At this point, a sufficient amount was collected, but from the above article, it seems that GraphQL is used not only in Twitter Web Client but also in Twitter Mobile Client and Tweetdeck, so I decided to extract it from there.
In the code of Twitter Android Client, the pair of Endpoint name and Random String was stored in l63.java, and in Tweetdeck, it was bundle.[Hex string].js.


As a result, I have gathered a list of over 700 endpoints, so I decided to move to the next stage.

Testing

Testing over 700 endpoints can be a daunting task, but existing GraphQL clients don't support this type of endpoint, so I started testing with Firefox and the Burp Suite.
The test was run for several hours, so I will only pick and explain what is important.
First, it seems that there is no problem if GraphQL's endpoint is just /graphql.
You can execute GraphQL by sending a POST request with queryId (this is the Random String above) and variables in Body to this endpoint. So the Endpoint name was not needed.

Second, some Query IDs will give an error when trying to reference a field that does not exist.
This is probably due to an attempt to execute an old query on the current schema.

After testing for a while, I concluded that it is impossible to execute arbitrary GraphQL queries.
That's why I decided to run the queries one by one and drill down into the interesting ones.
After a while, I focused on the ListMembers query.
It looks like this is a query that returns a list of members for a List. And there was no check that the target List was private or not in that query.

Reporting

I found that I could retrieve the members of a private List using the ListMembers query (iUmNRKLdkKVH4WyBNw9x2A), so I reported this to Twitter.
A few hours later, there was a reply from the Twitter Security Team, but it seems that the Twitter team thinks the Twitter ID is difficult to brute force.
I thought that brute force is possible, so I tried creating a script to try brute force. However, due to the existence of rate limits, it was not possible to brute force.

Bypassing

Direct brute force cannot be done because the rate limit of GraphQL itself cannot be avoided. However, the List-ID is not unique to GraphQL and is used in various APIs. Therefore, I decided to try using these APIs to see if brute force is possible.
Fortunately, Twitter's API rate limits were mostly broken. Even though Twitter's developer docs said that there was a rate limit, there were many that didn't.
However, it seems that there is no vulnerability in the API of Twitter that leaks information on the private List, and it is not possible to confirm the existence of the private List.
At this point, I was considering self-closing the report. But it was not fun to give up here, so I decided to explore more possibilities.
After a few minutes, I noticed the presence of the x-response-time header. This seems to be returning the time used for processing on the server-side.
I immediately confirmed the difference in the x-response-time header when specifying the ID of the private List and when specifying the ID that does not exist.
There was a slight difference (10-20ms) in processing time between private List ID and non-existent ID. Using this, I can enumerate the IDs on any private List.

Exploiting

After creating a PoC that enumerates a List using the above vulnerabilities, I was hungry and decided to eat ramen.
Before I went to eat ramen, I deployed PoC to AWS and ran it.
After returning home, I checked my AWS instance and rejoiced.
Potential List Detected: [Real List ID] (With 137ms delay)
It looks like I found valid private List ID...
And yes, I've confirmed that I can read members of any private List!

Conclusion

I think this report is a good report showing that even a small vulnerability (confirmation of the existence of a private List) that is not normally recognized as a valid report can produce a greater effect by being linked with other vulnerabilities.
Also, by using the same technique like this one, you can enumerate all the Moments using the link-only sharing option that exists in Twitter's Moment function, but this does not seem to be a vulnerability (Twitter closed it as Informative.)

Unfortunately, when I was looking for a Twitter vulnerability after this report, my account was suspended. (I haven't received a reply from the support team yet...)
(Edit: My account got unsuspended)
So I can't find any more Twitter vulnerabilities. Therefore, I'll share here some of the interesting information I found during my research. (If you find vulnerabilities based on this information, I would be grateful for a word of thanks.)

PoC files

brutemoment.go (F935333): It'll find unlisted moments (Intended behavior)
twileak.rb (F935334): It'll find valid List ID

Twitter GraphQL Query IDs

Web-Current.txt (F935320)
Android.txt (F935321)
Web-All.txt (F935322)
Tweetdeck.txt (F935323)

About protected tweets option

Twitter's protected tweets option only protects Tweets. It won't protect Lists, Followers... etc.
If you're using a protected account and sharing some sensitive information in Lists, be careful with it. (Twitter said this is intended behavior.)

Broken rate limits

After sending this report, I deleted the list of endpoints that have the broken rate limit. And as my account got suspended, I can't test it anymore. So please find it by yourself.

If you have any questions, ask me on Twitter ;)
